s.text: But in this year's cable indecency case, known as Denver Consortium , four Supreme Court justices were willing to use Pacifica as a guide for cable television as well as over-the-air broadcasting.
A three-judge federal court was probably correct in striking down the CDA June 11.

Denver Consortium followed the same pattern: It struck down a restriction on indecent speech because there were other effective alternatives available; but it suggested that such a restriction might be constitutional if it were, in fact, the only effective way to shield children.
A three-judge federal court was probably correct in striking down the CDA June 11.

FCC (1990), in which the court struck down a ban on dial-a-porn.

Does this extra protection justify the considerable spillover?

Does this extra protection justify the considerable spillover?
Does this extra protection justify the considerable spillover?
Does this extra protection justify the considerable spillover?
There's no right to say, "Your money or your life" to a stranger in a dark alley; there's no right to spread intentional falsehoods about your product or your enemy's character.

Virtually any sort of speech in the public areas of cyberspace is available to minors, so the law really applies to all such areas, including Web sites, Internet newsgroups, e-mail discussion lists, chat rooms, and bulletin boards.
My guess is that the marginal benefit of the CDA over the technological alternatives is small enough, and the burden that the law creates is large enough, that the CDA will be overturned.
Dozens of Web sites are being added daily, and you never know what will get posted tomorrow even on existing sites or newsgroups.
